text:
Fifth Avenue, at Waverly Place, Washington Square and southern extremity. The tall building in the background is an apartment house at 1 Fifth Avenue.

About 1930.

Ewing Galloway, Photographer.

A general view of the downtown skyline as photographed southward from the apartment building, No. 1 Fifth Avenue. From the left to the right the shadowy outlines are identified as, the American Sugar Refining Bldg. No 120 Wall St., the Municipal Bldg., the City Bank - Farmers Trust Co. Bldg. (under construction), the Bank of Manhattan Bldg., the Woolworth Bldg., the Singer Bldg., the New York Telephone Co. Bldg., the Western Union Bldg., and another New York Telephone Co. Bldg. Through the center foreground runs the old Sixth Avenue Elevated Line on West Broadway.

Autumn 1930

Gift of Bernhard Hoffman
William Frange, photo
94 Pineapple St., Bklyn, N.Y.
title: General view - Downtown Manhattan - [View of skyline.]

text:
Washington Square Park: The Garibaldi bronze by G. Turini; presented to the City by the Italians of the United States and erected here in 1888. It stands in the N.E. corner of the park. The apartment house shown is No. 1 Fifth Ave. and forms an interesting contrast.

September 26, 1936.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: Washington Square Park

text:
Fifth Avenue, east side, north from Waverly Place to Washington Mews, showing the buildings that are the Sailors Snug Harbor holdings, subsequent to reconstruction. The Washington Arch, is on the right and Waverly Place intervenes between same and the building fronts. The Mews is on the left and runs along the side of the towering apartment house, No. 1 Fifth Avenue.
View 2 is eastward from the Avenue and shows details of the pergola court yard between the apartments and their former rear stables. The dominant apartment in the background is No. 1 University Place.

P. L. Sperr

June 9, 1940
Views 1,2

Fifth Avenue, N.E. corner, looking towards Waverly Place, showing remodeling of residences. Also large apartment house at No. 1 Fifth Avenue.

P. L. Sperr

May 10, 1939

May 10, 1939

Artists & Poets-Greenwich Village: The Outdoor Art Exhibit at Washington Square with the Arch, Allan Segar tree and the distinctive apartment house, No. 1 Fifth Avenue for a backdrop. This is a semi-annual event; there being both a Fall and a Spring showing.

1939

Alexander Alland

This photo is one of the series that appeared in the published volume "Portrait of New York" by Felix Reisenberg and Alexander Alland. IRGV
title: Artists and poets - Greenwich Village.
